text: I see that you have some Matlab code <@U01BZJ2JTML>. Do you have a Julia version? What’s the license on that code?  And how do you define the H function?

elements.text: I see that you have some Matlab code
. Do you have a Julia version? What’s the license on that code?  And how do you define the H function?

text:
yes: <https://github.com/AnderGray/Hvolume-Matlab>

I don’t have it in julia yet, but can port it over sometime. The measure in matlab is just an anon function, can be any multivariate cdf. Copulas are used in the example, which are n-d cdfs with uniform marginals. Will add a license sometime also.

elements.text: yes:

text: yeah, a 1D cdf is P(X <= x). So a 2d one would be P(X <= x, Y <=y)

elements.text: yeah, a 1D cdf is P(X <= x). So a 2d one would be P(X <= x, Y <=y)

text: This is usually a difficult thing to calculate though, I think?

elements.text: This is usually a difficult thing to calculate though, I think?

text: There are lots of cases where changing representation is hard. I'd think the point might be that it's sometimes convenient to start with something like this, so there's no conversion necessary. <@U01BZJ2JTML> does that sound right?

elements.text: There are lots of cases where changing representation is hard. I'd think the point might be that it's sometimes convenient to start with something like this, so there's no conversion necessary.
does that sound right?

text: Yes, usually you have an analytical form for the pdf and the cdf can only be found through integration. The multivariate gaussian cdf for example has no analytical solution.

elements.text: Yes, usually you have an analytical form for the pdf and the cdf can only be found through integration. The multivariate gaussian cdf for example has no analytical solution.

text:
There are some advantages from starting from the cdf though:

• You already have the integral, so finding the measure is easy (h-volume)
• You can get the lower dimensional marginals by taking one variable to the extreme: P(X <=x ) = P(X <=x, Y <= inf). The same calculation with densities involves an integration
• You can decompose n-d cdfs into copulas and univariate cdfs: H(x,y) = C( F(x), G(y) )
Where C is a copula, and is just a n-d cdf with uniform marginals. It can store any probabilistic dependency

elements.text: There are some advantages from starting from the cdf though:
You already have the integral, so finding the measure is easy (h-volume)
You can get the lower dimensional marginals by taking one variable to the extreme: P(X <=x ) = P(X <=x, Y <= inf). The same calculation with densities involves an integration
You can decompose n-d cdfs into copulas and univariate cdfs: H(x,y) = C( F(x), G(y) )
Where C is a copula, and is just a n-d cdf with uniform marginals. It can store any probabilistic dependency

text: We need a copulas package in julia. I have some bivariate ones in ProbabilityBoundsAnalysis.jl, but would be good to have something fully N-D

elements.text: We need a copulas package in julia. I have some bivariate ones in ProbabilityBoundsAnalysis.jl, but would be good to have something fully N-D

text: To be honest though, I’m not sure how copulas would work outside probability theory. Or if something equivalent exists for general measures
